content.definition: An immune-mediated prothrombotic disorder caused by platelet-activating antibodies against platelet factor 4 (PF4) complexed with heparin. Despite causing thrombocytopenia, HIT paradoxically increases thrombosis risk, making it a critical diagnosis in hospitalized patients on heparin.

mechanism: Heparin binds to platelet factor 4 (PF4) on platelets

timing: Rapid onset if heparin exposure in past 100 days

laboratory.approach: Use 4Ts → if intermediate/high → ELISA → if positive → SRA

management.stop_heparin: ALL heparin including flushes, coated catheters
alternative_anticoagulation: Argatroban (hepatic metabolism) - most common in US
avoid_warfarin: Warfarin depletes protein C → venous limb gangrene

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features and timing of HIT
Use the 4Ts score for pretest probability
Know management: stop heparin, start non-heparin anticoagulant
clinical_pearls: HIT is a PROTHROMBOTIC disorder despite low platelets - DO NOT transfuse
Day 5-14 timing is classic; earlier if prior heparin in 100 days
>50% platelet drop more important than absolute count
DO NOT start warfarin until platelets >150K (risk of venous limb gangrene)
4Ts score: low score rules out HIT; high score = treat empirically
Argatroban in US; bivalirudin for PCI; fondaparinux off-label but effective
